PIONEER EXPERIENCES

A word of explanation to the person answering this questionnaire:

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual was exposed to exactly the same experiences as another. Some of the questions here will not apply to your experiences; others may prove impossible for you to answer, so don't worry about leaving blank spaces.

Don't hesitate to give details where there is not sufficient space to answer the question. Don't hesitate to give details, or describe particular events, if they help to answer the questions.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1914, but may be supplementary anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

Other Questionnaires

Saskatchewan Archives questionnaires which have been prepared or projected are listed below. Please mark the ones you would be willing to answer.

- All questionnaires
- Pioneer diet
- Pioneer schools
- Pioneer churches
- Pioneer recreation and social life
- Pioneer farming experiences
- Pioneers in Saskatchewan
- Pioneers health and housing

Preservation of Questionnaires

All questionnaires will be preserved in the Office of the Saskatchewan Archives at the University of Saskatchewan as part of the permanent record of our Province. Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Saskatchewan.

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

NOTE: Please print all proper names and place names in capital letters. If you are not sure the name is correct as you have given it, please make no correction. It is quite acceptable to have someone else do this writing at your dictation.

1. Your full name: Francis George Frost
2. Your address: The Drive, Bulkhurst Hill, Essex, England
3. Date: 15/8/1886
4. Where were you born? Leytonstone—Essex—England
5. What was your father's name and occupation? John Hayles Frost
6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? August, 1904
7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan, giving dates wherever possible.
   - Leytonstone 1886—1902
   - Southend 1902—1904
8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to answer this question if you would rather not or you may use "I was a small child," "I was in my teens," etc.)
9. What were your reasons for coming West?
   - Following advice from Railway resident and love of the West, much advertised at that time in England.
10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people? Reading about it? Railroad or government information?)

General immigration & government advertisement, also general reading.
FRANCIS GEORGE FROST
4 THE DRIVE, BULCHURST HILL, ESSEX, ENGLAND

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

NOTE: Please print all proper names and places names in capital letters. If you are not sure the name is correct as you have given it, please sign it. It is quite acceptable to have someone else do the writing at your dictation.

1. Your full name: Francis George Frost
2. Your address: 4 The Drive, Bulchurst Hill, Essex, England
3. Date: 13/8/1886
4. Where were you born? (Give name of place and country): Leytonstone - Essex - England
5. What was your father's name and occupation?: John Hayles Frost
6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month and year): August, 1904
7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan, giving dates whenever possible:
   - Leytonstone 1886-1904
   - Southend
8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to answer this question if you were under 18 years of age or you may use "I was a small child," etc.) I was 18 years old.
9. What were your reasons for coming West?
   Following ads for railway accident and live off the land, much advertised at that time in England.
10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people? Reading about it? Railroad or government information?) General newspaper & government advertisement, also general reading.
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?

mostly approval.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other group)?

By myself (making casual travel).

13. What means of transportation did you use?

Steamer & C.P.R. (Edmonton-Calgary)

V.J.S. Kanawha

14. What incidents of the journey West do you remember? (People you met on the way; meetings with Indians; adventures on the journey; accidents or other excitement, etc.)

various short trips interesting but not a smooth journey throughout, making especially well-known people.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?

Into St. James Boarding House

2nd Avenue, Saskatoon.

16. Where did you settle or take up land?

S.E. corner 10 mile due South of Saskatoon (then so called)

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How, after you came?

Before — Commercial Clerk

After — On farms — before entering Emmanuel College
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?

Mostly approval.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other group)?

By myself (making acquaintance)

13. What means of transportation did you use?

Steamer & C.P.R. (Railroad car)

V.S.S. Kanawha

14. What incidents of the journey best do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement, etc.)

A smooth journey throughout, meeting various short-trim interesting but trust especially well-known people.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?

My St. James Boarding House

2nd Avenue, Saskatoon

16. Where did you settle or take up land?

S.E. corner of Lots 18 & 19, Section 17, Township 21, Range 12, Saskatoon

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.

Graduate — Emmanuel College, Saskatoon

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How, after you came?

Before — Commercial Clerk

After — On farms — before entering Emmanuel College
19. How often did you write to relatives or friends in your old home?

20. If you got married, give the name of your husband or wife along with the date and place of marriage.

21. Did anyone else come to Saskatchewan because of your recommending it as a place to settle?

Robert Hosland whom I think is now in Canada in the Baptist Ministry.

22. If other members of your family (brothers, sisters, parents, etc.) came West tell when they came and where they settled.

None

23. Is there any particular experience of pioneer days that stands out in your memory which you would like to record?

Very many small yet not unimportant acts which would make a not uninteresting and informing book e.g. a quarantine and brief meeting with Bishop of Lloyd and brief meeting with Lord Grey, Governor-General of Canada, 1909.

24. Did you travel about much in the early years? (For business, attending church, visiting friends, etc.) How often? How far? By what means of travel?

Grizzled not more than 20 miles from Saskatoon in charge of 6-8 miles in villages.

25. Occasional infrequent journey to Diocesan Synod at Prince Albert Cathedral where I was ordained Deacon (1913) and Priest (1914).

   - Yes. Naturally more railway than by all quarters. Only C.N.R. in 1904 Regina.

29. How often did you shop in the early days?
   - About once a week, on average.

30. When (if ever) did people in your district first start going to town regularly on Saturdays?
   - [Blank]

31. When (if ever) did you first begin to buy through the mail order catalogues? What kind of articles did you buy in this way? Indicate also what fraction of your total purchases were by mail order and any changes in the proportion of purchases made by mail order since the pioneer period.

33. When you came to Saskatchewan the first time was it with the idea of staying permanently? Or did you make up your mind after trying it out? When did you make this decision?
   - No fixed determination to remain permanently.

The 1914-18 war finally decided return.
